MES
VOL. XXV. No. 11
"JOHNNY" KNIPP TO COACH
LACROSSE
Will Be Assisted by Henry Baker, '17,
and Eddie Hulburt, '15.—Navy
to be Met at Homewood in
Spring.

John C. Knipp, '17, has been
selected as head coach of the lacrosse team for 1921. Knipp is
well known by all the University
as one of the best lacrosse players
ever developed at Hopkins, having
been on the varsity for several
years, and captain in 1917. Since
graduating he has played first attack on the Mt. Washington independent team and has been one
of its stars.
He -will have as assistant
coaches Henry Baker,'17, and Edward Hulburt,'15. The Schmeiser
brothers and Reaney Wolfe, who
have handled the squad so successfully for many years, will be
on hand as much as possible to
lend their valuable aid in whipping the team into shape.
One of the biggest games on the
schedule for next Spring will be
that with the United States Naval
Academy. "Final arrangements
have been made which will bring
the Navy team to Baltimore to
play the Varsity at Homewood
Field on May 14. This game will
be of great interest to all, and
especially to those who have followed the games with Navy in the
past few years. This is the first
occasion on which Navy's team has
been allowed to play a lacrosse
game away from its 'grounds at
Annapolis. All indications point
to .a contest to rival in intensity
and importance the championship
game with Lehigh.
A big organization meeting will
be held on Wednesday, December
15, at 4 o'clock, in Room 110 M.
E. At this time Johnny Knipp
and the other coaches will be on
hand to make short addresses. The
meeting will be of special interest
to those who have been on the
squad this fall, as well as to those
who desire to play lacrosse next
Spring.
A. A. ASSOCIATION THANKS
USHERS.

The A thle ti e Association,
through Mr. Kistler, Graduate
Manager, wishes to extend its
sincere thanks to the students
of the University who acted as
ushers during the Hopkins football season and at the big NavyMarine game on December 4.
These men, despite the thankless
positions which they held, carried out their duties in an exceptionally faithful and efficient
manner, and their work is greatly appreciated by those in
charge of that department of
the football management.

BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 14, 1920
NON-ATHLETIC FEE PASSED.

BILL WOOD ELECTED CAPTAIN.

Trustees Ratify Petition at Last Meeting—Goes Into Effect Next Year.

Unanimously Chosen to Head 1921
Football Squad—Banquet Big
Success.

At its regular meeting last week
the Board of Trustees of the University acted most favorably upon
the petition presented to it requesting the annual collection by
the treasurer of a non-athletic fee
to be utilized for the support of
the several non-athletic activitieS
upon the campus. The levying of
this, money to the amount of $10
from each undergraduate student
will be commenced next fall, and
will be collected in the same manner as the Athletic Fee which has
been in effect for some years.
The allotment • and distribution
of the money collected under the
conditions of the Non-Athletic
Fee will be under the supervision
and direction of a committee appointed by the Board of Collegiate
Students, which will co-operate
with the Varsity Seal Voting
Council, thus assuring absolute
fairness to all the activities concerned, as well as to the.students
themselves.. in return for the
money they pay in, each student
will receive subscriptions to the
different Hopkins publications and
tickets admitting them to the Dratratic Club play, the intercollegip te debates held at Homewood
and to the Musical Club concerts,
for which they have formerly paid
separately.
The Non-Athletic Fee was
brought up to the notice of the
leaders of the other activities by
several members of the NEWSLETTER Board some months ago,
and, after some discussion in reference to allotments and the like,
(Continued on page 5, col. 2)
BRAMBLE ELECTED EDITOR-INCHIEF.

P. Fulton Bramble has been
elected editor-in-chief of the Black'
and Blue Jay to till the term of
George R. Goetz, who expects to
leave college after February.
CHESS TOURNAMENT DEC. 20.

The J. H. U. Chess Club will
hold a tournament beginning December 20 and ending January 10.
The games will be played at the
"Barn," third floor (former
NEWS-LETTER office). All entries
must be in by Friday, December
17.
The men that will rank highest
in this tournament will represent
the J. H. U. Chess Club in several
matches with teams of other universities. All candidates aie requested to hand in a note bearing
name, box number and time most
convenient for play to Box 148.
Anyone that desires, to learn the
game will be assigned &tutor upon
applying to Kurrehnyer, Barnhart or Zuhin.

Bill Wood has been elected
captain of the Johns Hopkins
football team for next year.
At the banquet of the football
squad, held last Friday night at
the Emerson Hotel, he was unanimously selected to lead the Black
and Blue in the 1921 campaign.
No other nominations were made.
Bill was nominated and The
nomination seconded. While some
one was moving that nominations
be closed, another man called for
a unanimous election. The formal
call for a vote was hardly needed,
for a great shout of acclamation
had settled the matter and elected
one of the best captains the team
has ever had.
Bill Wood is without a doubt
one of the most popular men to
represent the Black and Blue on
the gridiron for many years. For
three years he has held down an
end position on the team, and has
shown a quality of play good
enough to win him a place on any
eleven in the country. Throughout all this time he has played
with a dash that bewildered his
opponents, and with the grit and
fight that never gives up. The new
captain promises to be a real
leader in every sense.

members of the squad were pre(Continued on page 5, col. 2)
DR. COHEN MAKES ADDRESS.

At the last meeting of the
Scientific Club on Thursday, December 9, the Club was addressed
by Dr. A. Cohen on the subject of
"Fermat's Last Theorem." Dr.
Cohen first gave an interesting
talk on the history of this famous
theorem, and then presented a
simple method for finding all sets
of three numbers which may form
the three sides of a• right triangle.
At its next meeting the Club
will be addressed by Dr. A. H.
Pfund of the Physics Department
on the subject of "Mirror Polish."
This meeting, which was erroneously announced for December 9,
will be held on Thursday, December 16, at 12.30 o'clock, in Room 2.
JUNIORS FILL VACANCIES.

*Christopher
Johnston
was
elected to fill the vacancy existing
on the Student Council at the
meeting of the Junior Class held
in the C. E. Hall on Friday at
12.20 o'clock.
•
R. N. Wood and Paul Parsons
were the successful candidates in
the class election for the Cotillion
Club.
The meeting .adjourned
after a futile discussion of the
prior attendance at class meetings.

PRICE 10 CENTS
0. D. K. INITIATES
NEW MEMBERS

NINE

Public Initiation Held at Thursday's
Assembly—Alexander Wolfe Explains Purpose of Fraternity.
Dean Makes Appeal.

The assembly of last week was
devoted chiefly to a public initiation of the Omicron Delta Kappa,
at which nine men were admitted
to membership. Graham Heiner,
president of the fraternity, presided and introduced "Alec"
Wolfe,'18, a former president, who
made a short address on the purposes of the society.
The 0. D. K., he said, should
mean more than the Phi Beta
Kappa; the latter is an award for
brains, which the Omicron initiate
must also possess, and at the same
time be a real man and a leader
of men. Rewarding as it does excellence in all the phases of college activity, the society should be
the highest aim of each student.
It would then be the natural
thing to expect such a body of men
to take the lead in the consideration of any question vitally affecting the students. It's a concrete
example, the speaker thinks it the
duty of the 0. D. K. to ascertain
the different opinions in the present football controversy with the
University of Maryland, to take a
definite stand, and then to stick
to it until the matter is settled.
Following Mr. Wolfe's address,
the fraternity key was awarded to
the following men:
H. R. Mullikin—Track Captain,
President of the Senior Class,
Member of the A. A. Board.,
Bartus Trew—President of the
Dramatic Club, Member of Cast
for two years, Secretary of the
A. A. Board, Business Manager
of Black and Blue Jay.
F. F. Bramble—Honor Student
for three years, an Editor of the
Black and Blue Jay, Member of
the Hullabaloo Staff and President of the Oratorical Society.
C. I. T. Gould—Manager and

"H" FOR MANAGERS?
• near
At a mass-meeting in the
future, the Student body will be
called upon to vote upon the
question of the awarding of H's
to the managers of football,
baseball and track. Heretofore,
the managers of these branches
of sport have received HM's for
their work, but at the last meeting of the Athletic Association
Board a resolution, • placing
managers on the same plane as
players, was passed for reference to the undergraduate body.

Why do so many men "get off"
straight Turkish cigarettes?

V.—Johns Hopkins Hospital Bulletin.
Monthly. 4to. Volume XXXI in
progress. $3.00 per year. (Foreign
postage 50 cents.)

T'S not always a matter of price. Many can afford
straight Turkish cigarettes, expensive as they are.

VI.—Johns Hopkins Hospital Reports.
4to. Volume XX in progress. $5.00
per volume. (Foreign postage 50 cents.)

I

The real reason is that straight Turkish cigarettes contain
too much Turkish for steady smoking. They are over-rich
—even heavy.
Men, for the most part, turn to part-Turkish or Turkish
Blend cigarettes. And in a great many cases are disappointed. Why? Because the ordinary Turkish Blend contains too little Turkish—it lacks taste.
No doubt this explains Fatima's popularity with discriminating smokers.
For while Fatima does not contain too much Turkish,
still it contains more than any other Turkish Blend—in
other words “just enough Turkish" to please not tire,
the taste.

BASKETBALL SQUAD SHAPING UP WELL
Much Promising Material Out. F irst
Game with Penn College on December 30. Strict Training
Insisted Upon.

Basketball candidates have been
practicing at Friends' School for
the past week, and are rapidly
being whipped into form for the
opening game with Pennsylvania
College at the Fifth Regiment
Armory on December 30. Scrimmages are being held daily, and
the material, although none too
heavy, has shown great improvement. Practice at the Armory
commenced this week and Coach
Lamborn is laying the foundation of the team which will form
the Varsity.
Among the men reporting for
practice are Ed. Wood, Bill Wood,
Cashell, Landy, Jolson, Ashton,
Bauernschmidt, Bloerson of Hobart College, Cattanach of Friends'
School, Marchetti of Mt. St. Jos=
eph'S Gregg of Greenbriar Military'
Academy, Barrett of Loyola
College, and Jefferson of the University of Pennsylvania freshman
team. In addition to these men
there are numerous others reporting who will make strong bids for
varsity positions.
Coach Lamborn insists on strict
training rules, and with the cooperation of every man, is sure to
develop a winning team. The conditioning practices are still being
held in addition to regular scrimmages'so that by the time the first
game is played every man will be
in the pink of condition.
All in all, the prospects for a
successful season are very bright.

BALTIMORE, MD., DEC. 14, 1920

EDITORIAL
NON-ATHLETIC FEE.

SENIOR PRIVILEGE.

The Seniors are privileged in one
or more ways. College traditions
are different in various institutions, and grant the members of
the Senior class distinctions which
Make them more or less conspicuous. Hopkins permits the members
of the graduating class and no other undergraudates the privilege of
using the main entrance to Gilman Hall leading up from the
center of the quadrangle. This
means something which all Seniors
should realize and respect. "
There is a bronze shield of the
University in the middle of the
floor inside the entrance on which
DO one should tread. Of course,
some of the uninitiated will walk
over this shield without realizing
perhaps that by doing so they are
trampling on the emblem which
stands for so much.
It falls to the lot of the Seniors
to create such a spirit that all
true lovers of Hopkins and its traditions will glance at that shield
and walk by it with a deep realization of its meaning and be inspired
to add to the attainments which
men in the past have done to make
Hopkins as well known as it is
today.
The Seniors this year do not
seem to truly appreciate this privilege as they should. They should
all take advantage of it and make
it become one of the best known
of Hopkins' traditions.

Spring sports as high comparatively as the charges for the football
games.

teams to be used to pay dividends,

students as college sports?

the student Athletic Board now
over the policy of the Varsity
Club, and where can a check be
expected to prevent prohibitive
prices and the commercializing of
our sports?

Oratorical Club.

The Oratorical Club at its last
meeting, staged one of the most
interesting discussions heard this
year. A resolution "that political
prisoners in the United States
should be released," was presented
to the assembly. Mr. Langeluttig
denounced the motion in the most
fiery and exalted language characterizing the crime committed by
political prisoners in general, and
Mr. Debs in particular, as heinous and bloody. However, his
speech was refuted by Mr. Ades,
who supported the resolution and
endeavored to show that Mr. Debs
was a staunch old patriot. The
assembly agreed with Mr. Ades,
about 60 per cent. of the members
voting for the resolution.
A program has been prepared
for the next meeting which is expected to surpass last week's in
interest, if such a thing is conceivable. Mr. Ades will address
the club on "The Reprehensible
Conduct of Our Government Toward Russia." Mr. West will
speak on "Our Mexican Policy,"
and Mr. Bramble will deliver a
dissertation on "Immigration."
The discussions and debates in
the Oratorical Club are both interesting and enlightening, and
are sure to be enjoyed by all who
attend. The next meeting will be
on Piiday, December 17, at 1.30
P. M.

"JOHNNY" KNIPP TO COACH
LACROSSE
Will Be Assisted by Henry Baker, '17,
and Eddie Hulburt, '15.—Navy
to be Met at Homewood in
Spring.

John C. Knipp, '17, has been
selected as head coach of the lacrosse team for 1921. Knipp is
well known by all the University
as one of the best lacrosse players
ever developed at Hopkins, having
been on the varsity for several
years, and captain in 1917. Since
graduating he has played first attack on the Mt. Washington independent team and has been one
of its stars.
He -will have as assistant
coaches Henry Baker,'17, and Edward Hulburt,'15. The Schmeiser
brothers and Reaney Wolfe, who
have handled the squad so successfully for many years, will be
on hand as much as possible to
lend their valuable aid in whipping the team into shape.
One of the biggest games on the
schedule for next Spring will be
that with the United States Naval
Academy. "Final arrangements
have been made which will bring
the Navy team to Baltimore to
play the Varsity at Homewood
Field on May 14. This game will
be of great interest to all, and
especially to those who have followed the games with Navy in the
past few years. This is the first
occasion on which Navy's team has
been allowed to play a lacrosse
game away from its 'grounds at
Annapolis. All indications point
to .a contest to rival in intensity
and importance the championship
game with Lehigh.
A big organization meeting will
be held on Wednesday, December
15, at 4 o'clock, in Room 110 M.
E. At this time Johnny Knipp
and the other coaches will be on
hand to make short addresses. The
meeting will be of special interest
to those who have been on the
squad this fall, as well as to those
who desire to play lacrosse next
Spring.
A. A. ASSOCIATION THANKS
USHERS.

The A thle ti e Association,
through Mr. Kistler, Graduate
Manager, wishes to extend its
sincere thanks to the students
of the University who acted as
ushers during the Hopkins football season and at the big NavyMarine game on December 4.
These men, despite the thankless
positions which they held, carried out their duties in an exceptionally faithful and efficient
manner, and their work is greatly appreciated by those in
charge of that department of
the football management.

BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 14, 1920
NON-ATHLETIC FEE PASSED.

BILL WOOD ELECTED CAPTAIN.

Trustees Ratify Petition at Last Meeting—Goes Into Effect Next Year.

Unanimously Chosen to Head 1921
Football Squad—Banquet Big
Success.

At its regular meeting last week
the Board of Trustees of the University acted most favorably upon
the petition presented to it requesting the annual collection by
the treasurer of a non-athletic fee
to be utilized for the support of
the several non-athletic activitieS
upon the campus. The levying of
this, money to the amount of $10
from each undergraduate student
will be commenced next fall, and
will be collected in the same manner as the Athletic Fee which has
been in effect for some years.
The allotment • and distribution
of the money collected under the
conditions of the Non-Athletic
Fee will be under the supervision
and direction of a committee appointed by the Board of Collegiate
Students, which will co-operate
with the Varsity Seal Voting
Council, thus assuring absolute
fairness to all the activities concerned, as well as to the.students
themselves.. in return for the
money they pay in, each student
will receive subscriptions to the
different Hopkins publications and
tickets admitting them to the Dratratic Club play, the intercollegip te debates held at Homewood
and to the Musical Club concerts,
for which they have formerly paid
separately.
The Non-Athletic Fee was
brought up to the notice of the
leaders of the other activities by
several members of the NEWSLETTER Board some months ago,
and, after some discussion in reference to allotments and the like,
(Continued on page 5, col. 2)

P. Fulton Bramble has been
elected editor-in-chief of the Black'
and Blue Jay to till the term of
George R. Goetz, who expects to
leave college after February.
CHESS TOURNAMENT DEC. 20.

The J. H. U. Chess Club will
hold a tournament beginning December 20 and ending January 10.
The games will be played at the
"Barn," third floor (former
NEWS-LETTER office). All entries
must be in by Friday, December
17.
The men that will rank highest
in this tournament will represent
the J. H. U. Chess Club in several
matches with teams of other universities. All candidates aie requested to hand in a note bearing
name, box number and time most
convenient for play to Box 148.
Anyone that desires, to learn the
game will be assigned &tutor upon
applying to Kurrehnyer, Barnhart or Zuhin.

Bill Wood has been elected
captain of the Johns Hopkins
football team for next year.
At the banquet of the football
squad, held last Friday night at
the Emerson Hotel, he was unanimously selected to lead the Black
and Blue in the 1921 campaign.
No other nominations were made.
Bill was nominated and The
nomination seconded. While some
one was moving that nominations
be closed, another man called for
a unanimous election. The formal
call for a vote was hardly needed,
for a great shout of acclamation
had settled the matter and elected
one of the best captains the team
has ever had.
Bill Wood is without a doubt
one of the most popular men to
represent the Black and Blue on
the gridiron for many years. For
three years he has held down an
end position on the team, and has
shown a quality of play good
enough to win him a place on any

DR. COHEN MAKES ADDRESS.

At the last meeting of the
Scientific Club on Thursday, December 9, the Club was addressed
by Dr. A. Cohen on the subject of
"Fermat's Last Theorem." Dr.
Cohen first gave an interesting
talk on the history of this famous
theorem, and then presented a
simple method for finding all sets
of three numbers which may form
the three sides of a• right triangle.
At its next meeting the Club
will be addressed by Dr. A. H.
Pfund of the Physics Department
on the subject of "Mirror Polish."
This meeting, which was erroneously announced for December 9,
will be held on Thursday, December 16, at 12.30 o'clock, in Room 2.

PRICE 10 CENTS
0. D. K. INITIATES
NEW MEMBERS

NINE

Public Initiation Held at Thursday's
Assembly—Alexander Wolfe Explains Purpose of Fraternity.
Dean Makes Appeal.

The assembly of last week was
devoted chiefly to a public initiation of the Omicron Delta Kappa,
at which nine men were admitted
to membership. Graham Heiner,
president of the fraternity, presided and introduced "Alec"
Wolfe,'18, a former president, who
made a short address on the purposes of the society.
The 0. D. K., he said, should
mean more than the Phi Beta
Kappa; the latter is an award for
brains, which the Omicron initiate
must also possess, and at the same
time be a real man and a leader
of men. Rewarding as it does excellence in all the phases of college activity, the society should be
the highest aim of each student.
It would then be the natural
thing to expect such a body of men
to take the lead in the consideration of any question vitally affecting the students. It's a concrete
example, the speaker thinks it the
duty of the 0. D. K. to ascertain
the different opinions in the present football controversy with the
University of Maryland, to take a
definite stand, and then to stick
to it until the matter is settled.
Following Mr. Wolfe's address,
the fraternity key was awarded to
the following men:
H. R. Mullikin—Track Captain,
President of the Senior Class,
Member of the A. A. Board.,
Bartus Trew—President of the
Dramatic Club, Member of Cast
for two years, Secretary of the
A. A. Board, Business Manager
of Black and Blue Jay.
F. F. Bramble—Honor Student
for three years, an Editor of the
Black and Blue Jay, Member of
the Hullabaloo Staff and President of the Oratorical Society.

Why do so many men "get off"
straight Turkish cigarettes?

V.—Johns Hopkins Hospital Bulletin.

T'S not always a matter of price. Many can afford
straight Turkish cigarettes, expensive as they are.

VI.—Johns Hopkins Hospital Reports.
4to. Volume XX in progress. $5.00

I

The real reason is that straight Turkish cigarettes contain
too much Turkish for steady smoking. They are over-rich
—even heavy.
Men, for the most part, turn to part-Turkish or Turkish
Blend cigarettes. And in a great many cases are disappointed. Why? Because the ordinary Turkish Blend contains too little Turkish—it lacks taste.
No doubt this explains Fatima's popularity with discriminating smokers.
For while Fatima does not contain too much Turkish,
still it contains more than any other Turkish Blend—in
other words “just enough Turkish" to please not tire,
the taste.

BASKETBALL SQUAD SHAPING UP WELL
Much Promising Material Out. F irst
Game with Penn College on December 30. Strict Training
Insisted Upon.

Basketball candidates have been
practicing at Friends' School for
the past week, and are rapidly
being whipped into form for the
opening game with Pennsylvania
College at the Fifth Regiment
Armory on December 30. Scrimmages are being held daily, and
the material, although none too
heavy, has shown great improvement. Practice at the Armory
commenced this week and Coach
Lamborn is laying the foundation of the team which will form
the Varsity.
Among the men reporting for
practice are Ed. Wood, Bill Wood,
Cashell, Landy, Jolson, Ashton,
Bauernschmidt, Bloerson of Hobart College, Cattanach of Friends'
School, Marchetti of Mt. St. Jos=
eph'S Gregg of Greenbriar Military'
Academy, Barrett of Loyola
College, and Jefferson of the University of Pennsylvania freshman
team. In addition to these men
there are numerous others reporting who will make strong bids for
varsity positions.
Coach Lamborn insists on strict
training rules, and with the cooperation of every man, is sure to
develop a winning team. The conditioning practices are still being
held in addition to regular scrimmages'so that by the time the first
game is played every man will be
in the pink of condition.
All in all, the prospects for a
successful season are very bright.

EDITORIAL
NON-ATHLETIC FEE.

SENIOR PRIVILEGE.

The Seniors are privileged in one
or more ways. College traditions
are different in various institutions, and grant the members of
the Senior class distinctions which
Make them more or less conspicuous. Hopkins permits the members
of the graduating class and no other undergraudates the privilege of
using the main entrance to Gilman Hall leading up from the
center of the quadrangle. This
means something which all Seniors
should realize and respect. "
There is a bronze shield of the
University in the middle of the
floor inside the entrance on which
DO one should tread. Of course,
some of the uninitiated will walk
over this shield without realizing
perhaps that by doing so they are
trampling on the emblem which
stands for so much.
It falls to the lot of the Seniors
to create such a spirit that all
true lovers of Hopkins and its traditions will glance at that shield
and walk by it with a deep realization of its meaning and be inspired
to add to the attainments which
men in the past have done to make
Hopkins as well known as it is
today.
The Seniors this year do not
seem to truly appreciate this privilege as they should. They should
all take advantage of it and make
it become one of the best known
of Hopkins' traditions.

To the Editor of the News-Letter:
Dear Sir=-I should like to call
attention to the deplorable condition of the service flag which hangs
in the Assembly room. This flag,
which was hung in honor of the
eight hundred men from the University, who were in the service of
the country during the war, and
which carries some gold stars in
honor of those who died, has been
allowed to become very dirty. The
flag should either be removed altogether, if it is not to be cared for,
or it should be taken down and
cleaned. I hope this will be done,
at least, before the Cotillon.
"INTERESED."
Editor Mail Bag:
Sir—Now that the football season has closed, perhaps it would
not be unfair to ask the Varsity
Club for a general statement of
finances, so that the students may
gain a real idea of the state of
their treasury.
An universal protest ought to
come from the students if the Varsity Club decides to set the prices
for the basketball games and
Spring sports as high comparatively as the charges for the football
games.
It is true that certain payments
have been guaranteed by the Varsity Club, but are the Hopkins
teams to be used to pay dividends,
or are they to be enjoyed by the
students as college sports?
In fact, what real control has
the student Athletic Board now
over the policy of the Varsity
Club, and where can a check be
expected to prevent prohibitive
prices and the commercializing of
our sports?
A. M.

BOXING CLUB MAKING
PROGRESS
Gets Use of B. C. C. Gym.
Many
• Promising Candidates Out. Contests Arranged with Penn,
Columbia and Second
Team of Navy.

Oratorical Club.

The Oratorical Club at its last
meeting, staged one of the most
interesting discussions heard this
year. A resolution "that political
prisoners in the United States
should be released," was presented
to the assembly. Mr. Langeluttig
denounced the motion in the most
fiery and exalted language characterizing the crime committed by
political prisoners in general, and
Mr. Debs in particular, as heinous and bloody. However, his
speech was refuted by Mr. Ades,
who supported the resolution and
endeavored to show that Mr. Debs
was a staunch old patriot. The
assembly agreed with Mr. Ades,
about 60 per cent. of the members
voting for the resolution.
A program has been prepared
for the next meeting which is expected to surpass last week's in
interest, if such a thing is conceivable. Mr. Ades will address
the club on "The Reprehensible
Conduct of Our Government Toward Russia." Mr. West will
speak on "Our Mexican Policy,"
and Mr. Bramble will deliver a
dissertation on "Immigration."
The discussions and debates in
the Oratorical Club are both interesting and enlightening, and
are sure to be enjoyed by all who
attend. The next meeting will be
on Piiday, December 17, at 1.30
P. M.

DR. RYAN ADDRESSES
SOCIAL SCIENCE CLUB.
Dr. John A. Ryan of the Catholic University spoke before the
Social Science Club last Friday
taking as his subject "Roads to
Industrial Peace." Thisroad would
be clear, he said, should capital
allow labor to participate in the
Management of its industry.
Following the address, the lecturer was bombarded with questions from the audience, after
which ensued a lively discussion
before the end of the meeting.
